review.title: Machine Learning and Cloud Computing: Survey of Distributed and SaaS Solutions
review.abstract: Applying popular machine learning algorithms to large amounts of data raised new challenges for the ML practitioners. Traditional ML libraries does not support well processing of huge datasets, so that new approaches were needed. Parallelization using modern parallel computing frameworks, such as MapReduce, CUDA, or Dryad gained in popularity and acceptance, resulting in new ML libraries developed on top of these frameworks. We will briefly introduce the most prominent industrial and academic outcomes, such as Apache Mahout, GraphLab or Jubatus.

sections.text: Providers in this category offer computer clusters with public cloud providers, such as Amazon EC2, Rackspace, etc., pre-installed with statistics software, with preferred packages being R-System, Octave, or Mapple. These solutions provide their customers with scalable high-performance resources in the cloud that are freed from the burden of installing and managing their own clusters. Cloudnumbers.com 1 uses Amazon EC2 Providers to set up computer clusters that are pre-installed with scientific computing software, such as R-System, Octave, or Mapple. Customers benefit from a web interface where they can create their own workspaces, configure and monitor the cluster, upload records, or connect to public databases. sections.heading: 8 Conclusions and future work
sections.text: Our key findings are summarized below: (1) Existing programming paradigms expressing large-scale parallelism, such as MapReduce (MR) and the Message Passing Interface (MPI), are de facto choices for implementing ML-DM algorithms. Due to their ability to process large data sets and provide built-in resilience, MR has received increasing attention. (2) Machine learning in distributed environments has different approaches and offers viable and cost-effective alternatives to traditional ML and statistical applications that do not focus on distributed environments [14]. (3) Existing solutions target either experienced, qualified computer scientists, mathematicians, statisticians or inexperienced users who are not satisfied with (or few) opportunities to adapt the algorithms. Ens user support and guidance are largely absent from existing distributed ML-DM solutions. After reviewing offers on different telecommunications platforms, we think that there is still room for M2 / D2 solutions in the market.

metadata.abstractText: Applying popular machine learning algorithms to large amounts of data raised new challenges for the ML practitioners. Traditional ML libraries does not support well processing of huge datasets, so that new approaches were needed. Parallelization using modern parallel computing frameworks, such as MapReduce, CUDA, or Dryad gained in popularity and acceptance, resulting in new ML libraries developed on top of these frameworks. We will briefly introduce the most prominent industrial and academic outcomes, such as Apache Mahout, GraphLab or Jubatus. We will investigate how cloud computing paradigm impacted the field of ML. First direction is of popular statistics tools and libraries (R system, Python) deployed in the cloud. A second line of products is augmenting existing tools with plugins that allow users to create a Hadoop cluster in the cloud and run jobs on it. Next on the list are libraries of distributed implementations for ML algorithms, and on-premise deployments of complex systems for data analytics and data mining. Last approach on the radar of this survey is ML as Software-as-a-Service, several BigData start-ups (and large companies as well) already opening their solutions to the market.
